>From: "Mike Cavanaugh" <mike@...>
>Reply-To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
>To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
>Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: shinsa question
>Date: Fri, 13 Feb 2004 08:08:22 -0500
>
>Hello,
>I am new on this site and am also the recipient of about a dozen tsuba. I 
>was told that they are dated somewhere around the third century? My 
>question is where do I go to get an honest apraised value on these items. I 
>am not a collector of this type so have no earthly idea where to seek 
>information. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
>Thanks,
>Mike
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: yamaimojg [mailto:jggilbert@...]
>Sent: Thursday, February 12, 2004 10:32 PM
>To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: shinsa question
>
>
>Rick,
>Just saw your question.  As described it sounds like it's a koshirae
>that should pass shinsa.  The point to submitting it would be do get
>written certification of its age, completeness, quality, etc.
>Whether that is worth doing is up to you.  There should be an NTHK
>shinsa coming to a coast near you in the next couple or few years.
>
>Jim
>
>--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "nihontochicken" <rick@s...>
>wrote:
> > Hi, guys 'n' gals, thought I'd drop in momentarily.  Re the thread
>on
> > papering koshirae, can I solicit some advice on one of my
>few "attic
> > finds"?  The blade has already been papered (sent back to Japan,
> > papered hozon, nice old polish Eisho era unokubi zukuri, but
>tired).
> > The koshirae (not sent) has been assessed by One Who Should Know as
> > original and correct pre-Meiji, absolutely NSW (Not Screwed With).
> > Mostly in excellent condition, no wear or soil to the tsuka ito,
> > even.  I would guess that papering the koshirae would be a slam
>dunk,
> > except
> >
> > 1. The saya is dinged up.  Not terribly badly, but far from
> > pristine.  It would be a bastard to repair, because in strong
>light,
> > the "black" lacquer is seen to be black with translucent brown
> > streaks running through it.
> >
> > 2. The kashira is for correct court wear, i.e., it is black horn,
>not
> > a kinko match for the fuchi (which is signed, though the apparently
> > matching tsuba isn't).
> >
> > 3.  Though the tsuba has the hitsu, there are no accessories, and
>no
> > provisions for any in the saya.
> >
> > Sooooooo, would there be any real point to submitting this to
> > shinsa?  It is pre-Meiji original, but no "knock your socks off".
> > Just wondering, in case a shinsa shows up again on the US west
>coast
> > in my lifetime!
> >
> > NC  ;o)
>
>
>
